# Context

<div class="justtext">
<p style="font-size:calc(10px + 0.2vw); line-height:1.05;" align="middle">
This collaborative science program is one of the main research axis of the **[the research partnership on Ticks-Moose-Climate (TMC) interactions <i class="fa fa-external-link "> </i>](http://www.sites.google.com/view/tiqueorignalclimat){target="_blank"}**. This research partnership aims to understand and predict how winter tick and climate interaction impacts moose population dynamics in eastern Canada, considering actual and futur climate projections. 

In several areas in North America, winter ticks has been related to substancial population declines, and this is why we ask you to contribute as hunters, anglers, wildlife professionals or hikers, to help us gather critical information that will provide answers to important questions. 

We are actually starting the pilot phase of this program. We welcome your suggestions, comments, insights or questions at this mail adress [toc@bio.ulaval.ca](mailto:toc@bio.ulaval.ca). The developement of this collaborative science program is lead by a research team based at University Laval, in Québec city.

</p>

</div>

\
